channel.title: Project Insanity , perfect flax picking without an extreme deroute
channel.description:
So I looked around if anybody had 100% flax picking for PI yet , turned out some people on R-S had made it but used a whole new class for it...
I say fuck you to that , just keep it simple. Here's the code on how to make it work: (Sorry for my conventions ; they look much better on N++) [code=java] case 2646: c.turnPlayerTo(obX,obY); // 1 if (System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastPick > 3000) { // 2 if (c.getItems().freeSlots() != 0) { // 3 c.startAnimation(827); // 4 c.getItems().addItem(1779,1 // 5 c.lastPick = System.currentTimeMillis(); // 6 if (Misc.random(2) == 1) { // 7 new Object(-1, obX, obY, 0, 1, 10, 2646, 12); // 8 } } else { c.sendMessage("You don't have enough inventory space to do that."); return; } } else { return; } break; [/code] Let's explain our code a little shall we , 1)When the player clicks on the object , he will turn towards it no mater what.
2)Checks if the player has recently picked anything else The long value lastPick must be declared in the player class like so: [code=java]public long lastPick;[/code]
3)Check if the player has a free slot to add the flax
4)Perform the picking emote
5)Add the flax
6)Indicates the last time the player has picked anything as the current time
7)As most of you know , flax can be picked multiple times before it disapears , so here there's a 1/3 chance that the flax will disapear upon picking it
8)If the random number gets picked , the Object will be added as an Object to the processing list which is handled in the ObjectManager class. I won't explain you how that works , but I shall explain you the parameters for the Object Object : [code=java]new Object(tempObject, obX, obY, height, face, 10, endObject, ticks);[/code] A quick explenation of that : The object [b]tempObject[/b] will be placed at [b]obX,obY[/b] for as long as the [b]ticks[/b] variable hasn't reached 0. Once that reaches 0 , it will delete the [b]tempObject[/b] and replace it by the [b]endObject[/b].
To use the Object Object , you must import the Object class , like so : [code=java]import server.model.objects.Object;[/code]
Also note that the code snippet given above must be placed in [b]secondClickObject[/b] method in the ActionHandler class because the 'Pick' option is not the main action for that object.
I hope you enjoyed this little tutorial , I've explained some methods , the Object Object , and some other logic stuff. Enjoy your flax...

item.title: Project Insanity , perfect flax picking without an extreme deroute
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

[quote=“James-RevolutionX, post:9, topic:411474”]So much easier then that.

case 2646: c.objectTimer = System.currentTimeMillis(); c.getItems().addItem(1779, 1); c.startAnimation(827); break;[/quote]

If you’re being sarcastic , that code only does half of what it’s supposed to do.

[quote=“LilXCj, post:8, topic:411474”]Code shouldn’t be copy and pasted. That’s what you’re implying by “deleted”. Code should be written by the programmer. Also, documenting is recommended especially with methods like:

and

What is so hard with doing it this way?

and

Because obX and obY are parameters given in the method itself :

As for the Misc.random(value); thingy…

It’s easier to do

then to do

int x = 2; Misc.random(x)

Fridder:

Cool. How can this be useful? It’s great that you can pick flax, bank it, continue until your bored and do something else, but what’s the actual point of picking flax?

This can be usefull to economy servers or RS remakes (or at least the half assed ones with original content).
Making spinning isn’t hard , and the same goes for adding bow stringing…

Read full topic

@Muroth wrote:

Fridder:

Cool. How can this be useful? It’s great that you can pick flax, bank it, continue until your bored and do something else, but what’s the actual point of picking flax?

Spin it into bow string then string them onto bows gaining fletching XP.

item.title: Project Insanity , perfect flax picking without an extreme deroute
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

LilXCj:

Why is it at the bottom of the post instead of the top, where you should be giving information on what the person needs in order to proceed? This tutorial itself is laid out poorly and looks horrible. You don’t //1 then explain. There’s a reason why they are within the language. To document code to explain why it’s there.

I just felt more comfortable that way , and it’s also a way done by many other then me.
You give an example and then explain how it works.
The //1 , //2 etc indicate which part I’m explaining in the down part of the post and may be deleted as they are there for structuring reasons.

Read full topic

item.title: Project Insanity , perfect flax picking without an extreme deroute
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“LilXCj, post:3, topic:411474”]You don’t explain where the code goes, what classes are used. You just give us a snippet of code and tell us to put it somewhere hoping it works. This isn’t a tutorial. It’s not teaching me anything either. By the time I have a server I should know what (opcodes/packets) create objects and how to implement it. I should also know that using a currentSystemTime timer is worse than using process().

It doesn’t teach me anything other than to stop using Delta because of shit like this:

Client c = new Client;

as a stupid ass shortcut.[/quote]
But, not all leechers even knows half of what he’s talking about. It’s better than any other snippet being posted here…

item.title: Project Insanity , perfect flax picking without an extreme deroute
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

So I looked around if anybody had 100% flax picking for PI yet , turned out some people on R-S had made it but used a whole new class for it…

I say fuck you to that , just keep it simple.
Here’s the code on how to make it work:
(Sorry for my conventions ; they look much better on N++)

	case 2646:
		c.turnPlayerTo(obX,obY); // 1
		if (System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastPick > 3000) { // 2
			if (c.getItems().freeSlots() != 0) { // 3
				c.startAnimation(827); // 4
				c.getItems().addItem(1779,1 // 5
				c.lastPick = System.currentTimeMillis(); // 6
				if (Misc.random(2) == 1) { // 7
					new Object(-1, obX, obY, 0, 1, 10, 2646, 12); // 8
				}
			} else {
				c.sendMessage("You don't have enough inventory space to do that.");
				return;
			}
		} else {
			return;
		}
	break;

Let’s explain our code a little shall we ,
1)When the player clicks on the object , he will turn towards it no mater what.

2)Checks if the player has recently picked anything else
The long value lastPick must be declared in the player class like so:

3)Check if the player has a free slot to add the flax

4)Perform the picking emote

5)Add the flax

6)Indicates the last time the player has picked anything as the current time

7)As most of you know , flax can be picked multiple times before it disapears , so here there’s a 1/3 chance that the flax will disapear upon picking it

8)If the random number gets picked , the Object will be added as an Object to the processing list which is handled in the ObjectManager class.
I won’t explain you how that works , but I shall explain you the parameters for the Object Object :

A quick explenation of that :
The object tempObject will be placed at obX,obY for as long as the ticks variable hasn’t reached 0.
Once that reaches 0 , it will delete the tempObject and replace it by the endObject.

To use the Object Object , you must import the Object class , like so :

Also note that the code snippet given above must be placed in secondClickObject method in the ActionHandler class
because the ‘Pick’ option is not the main action for that object.

I hope you enjoyed this little tutorial , I’ve explained some methods , the Object Object , and some other logic stuff.
Enjoy your flax…

Read full topic
